questions.question: Where does the idea for a bill usually originate from?
answers: The President
Supreme Court Justices
Citizens and Interest Groups
State Governors

questions.question: Who drafts a new bill once it is introduced?
answers: The President
The Speaker of the House
A Senator from the opposing party
A Representative known as the 'sponsor'

questions.question: Who assigns a bill to a committee in the House of Representatives?
answers: The President
The Speaker of the House
The Vice President
The Majority Leader of the Senate

questions.question: What is the role of subcommittees in the legislative process?
answers: They draft the final version of the bill.
They vote on the bill before it goes to the full chamber.
They carry out investigations and hearings related to the bill.
They introduce the bill to Congress.

questions.question: What happens during a 'markup session'?
answers: The bill is debated by the entire chamber.
The subcommittee proposes amendments to the bill.
The President signs or vetoes the bill.
The bill is introduced to the other chamber of Congress.

questions.question: What is a 'discharge petition'?
answers: A method to send a bill directly to the President.
A way for the House of Representatives to bring a bill to the floor after 30 days in committee.
A procedure to remove a bill from consideration in Congress after 30 days in committee.
A tool used by the Senate to delay voting on a bill.

questions.question: Who sets the order of debate in the House of Representatives?
answers: The Vice President
The Speaker of the House
The Senate Majority Leader
The President Pro Tempore

questions.question: How do the House of Representatives and the Senate differ in their debate rules?
answers: The House allows filibusters while the Senate does not.
The House operates under structured debate with time limits, while the Senate allows more flexible discussion.
The Senate operates under structured debate with time limits, while the House allows more flexible discussion.
Both chambers operate under the same debate rules.

questions.question: What happens if the versions of a bill passed by the House and the Senate are not identical?
answers: The President decides which version to sign.
The bill is sent back to the committee for redrafting.
A conference committee is formed to reconcile the differences.
The bill is automatically vetoed.

questions.question: What can Congress do if the President vetoes a bill?
answers: The veto can be overridden by a simple majority vote in both houses.
The veto can be overridden by a 2/3 supermajority vote in both houses.
The Supreme Court can override the veto.
The bill is automatically passed into law without changes.
